newsitem.title: UK: BAA sees 5 pct 1997 Heathrow cargo growth.
newsitem.headline: BAA sees 5 pct 1997 Heathrow cargo growth.

text.p: BAA Plc forecasts that London Heathrow Airport will handle an increase of five percent, or 70,000 tonnes, of cargo and mail on top of the 1.14 million tonnes recorded for 1996.
The strength of sterling limited the growth in UK air exports with the total only 1.3 percent up on 1995, BAA head of cargo development Ian Robinson told Reuters in an interview.

"But this year there will be much more Heathrow cargo capacity available and this, coupled with positive response from our marketing efforts, gives me confidence to predict a five percent rise in throughput for the airport for 1997," he said.

In January, Heathrow handled 80,482 tonnes, up 5.4 percent on January 1996. In 1996 Heathrow accounted for over 802,000 tonnes out of the total throughput of 1.117 million tonnes at BAA's eight UK airports.

Robinson added that the forthcoming British parliamentary elections, which must take place in May at the latest, would see constraints in the soaring strength of sterling, thereby preventing the price of British exports becoming more unattractive to overseas buyers.
Robinson said that Heathrow presently had a "theoretical maximum handling capacity" of 1.4 million tonnes.

"But by 1999, when British Airways' new (150 million stg) World Cargo Centre opens, and other new handling developments are in operation, the airport will have a potential annual handling capacity of two million tonnes," he said.
BA's new facility will be able to handle some 800,000 tonnes of cargo each year, double the present total.
